path.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));
fill: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));
fill: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));
fill: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));
fill: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));
fill: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

rect.style: fill: light-dark(#ffffff, var(--ge-dark-color, #121212)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 118px; height: 1px; padding-top: 200px; margin-left: 1px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center; color: #000000;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

rect.style: fill: light-dark(#ffffff, var(--ge-dark-color, #121212)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 708px; height: 1px; padding-top: 45px; margin-left: 181px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center; color: #000000;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.p: - NumPy (Numerical Python) provides an efficient interface to store and operate on data buffer.
- Numpy is fast because its written in C and to some extend its strictly typed i.e. all items in the array has a same type and its defined.
- NumPy array is of fixed size.
- NumPy arrays are designed to be homogeneous, meaning all elements within the array must have the same data type and size

switch.text: - NumPy (Numerical Python) provides an efficient interface to store and operate on data buffer....

rect.style: fill: light-dark(#ffffff, var(--ge-dark-color, #121212)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 698px; height: 1px; padding-top: 145px; margin-left: 181px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center; color: #000000;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

p.style: color: light-dark(rgb(63, 63, 63), rgb(183, 183, 183)); scrollbar-color: rgb(226, 226, 226) rgb(251, 251, 251); line-height: 50%;

span.style: scrollbar-color: rgb(226, 226, 226) rgb(251, 251, 251); background-color: transparent; color: light-dark(rgb(63, 63, 63), rgb(183, 183, 183));

p.style: color: light-dark(rgb(63, 63, 63), rgb(183, 183, 183)); scrollbar-color: rgb(226, 226, 226) rgb(251, 251, 251); line-height: 50%;

span.style: scrollbar-color: rgb(226, 226, 226) rgb(251, 251, 251); background-color: transparent; color: light-dark(rgb(63, 63, 63), rgb(183, 183, 183));

p.span: - While creating array, if types do not match, numpy will upcast if possible (e.g. integers are upcast-ed to floats).

p.style: color: light-dark(rgb(63, 63, 63), rgb(183, 183, 183)); scrollbar-color: rgb(226, 226, 226) rgb(251, 251, 251); line-height: 50%;

span.style: scrollbar-color: rgb(226, 226, 226) rgb(251, 251, 251); background-color: transparent; color: light-dark(rgb(63, 63, 63), rgb(183, 183, 183));

p.span: - When updating value, numpy will downcast without raising any warning. E.x. floating value is truncated in an iterger array.

p.style: color: light-dark(rgb(63, 63, 63), rgb(183, 183, 183)); scrollbar-color: rgb(226, 226, 226) rgb(251, 251, 251); line-height: 50%;

span.style: scrollbar-color: rgb(226, 226, 226) rgb(251, 251, 251); background-color: transparent; color: light-dark(rgb(63, 63, 63), rgb(183, 183, 183));

p.span: random array, we can set "seed" so that same random array are generated each time: `np.random.seed(0)`

rect.style: fill: light-dark(#ffffff, var(--ge-dark-color, #121212)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 698px; height: 1px; padding-top: 225px; margin-left: 181px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center; color: #000000;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div:
- multi-dimension: Shape(a,b,c,d). Here array has 'a' items. Each 'a' item has 'b' items. Each 'b' item has 'c' items. And so on
- 2D: special case. Shape(row, column). First dimnesion/axis is called 'row'.

switch.text: - multi-dimension: Shape(a,b,c,d). Here array has 'a' items. Each 'a' item has 'b' items. Each 'b' item has 'c' item...

rect.style: fill: light-dark(#ffffff, var(--ge-dark-color, #121212)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 698px; height: 1px; padding-top: 315px; margin-left: 181px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center; color: #000000;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Slicing:
- Unlike python list slicing, array slice return "views" rather than "copies" of the array data. This means that if we modify sub-array, then the original array will change.
- `x2[:2, :2].copy()`: This creates copy rather than a view. Modifying this won't change the original array.

rect.style: fill: light-dark(#ffffff, var(--ge-dark-color, #121212)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 698px; height: 1px; padding-top: 410px; margin-left: 181px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center; color: #000000;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div:
- Reshaping: Change the shape. It
works when the size of initial array matches the size of reshaped array.
- Concatenation: All the input array dimensions except for the concatenation axis must match exactly. By default, concatenation happens along first axis (axis=0) i.e. (2,3) + (2,3) = (4,3)
- Splitting: Opposite of concatenation. np.split(x, [a,b..n]) returns N+1 subarrays - [[0 to a-1], [a to b-1], ...[n to last item]]

switch.text: - Reshaping: Change the shape. ItÂ works when the size of initial array matches the size of reshaped array....

rect.style: fill: light-dark(#ffffff, var(--ge-dark-color, #121212)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 698px; height: 1px; padding-top: 510px; margin-left: 181px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center; color: #000000;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Computation:
- Vectorized operation: Simply perform operation on array, which will then be applied to each element.
- For fast computation, use vectorized operations, generally implemented through NumPy 'universal' functions (ufuncs).
- Arithmetic ufunc: e.g. x + 5. + operator is a wrapper round np.add()
